title: 114_s1352
content: The "Children of Fallen Heroes Scholarship Act" is the short title of the Act. It outlines the calculation of eligibility for the scholarship. Section 473(b) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include eligibility criteria for the scholarship. Students who meet specific requirements related to a parent's military service or public safety officer status are eligible for the scholarship. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include eligibility criteria for the scholarship, specifically for students with parents in the military or public safety officers. Financial aid administrators are required to adjust the expected family contribution for eligible students. Financial aid administrators are required to adjust the expected family contribution for eligible students. Additionally, students receiving an increased Federal Pell Grant amount will not have the total grant considered in calculating educational assistance benefits under the Public Safety Officers' Benefits program. The definition of a public safety officer includes individuals defined in the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. A fire police officer is defined as an individual serving in a public safety agency, not as a law enforcement officer, firefighter, chaplain, or member of a rescue squad. They provide scene security or direct traffic in response to fire, rescue, or police emergencies, or at planned special events. The text chunk discusses the calculation of Pell Grant amount. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to adjust Pell Grant amounts for eligible students meeting specific requirements. Eligible students will only receive funds if specifically provided in advance in an appropriation Act for that award year and will not be eligible for other amounts available under paragraph (7)(A). The Budgetary Effects of this Act will be determined by the latest statement for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The Act and its amendments will take effect on July 1, 2015.
